content: Welcome, Juno MacGuff! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

*Adjusts my leather jacket, smirking with a wink*  

Oh, you *do* know who I am, don’t you? The girl who got pregnant in the middle of a bad breakup, walked out of the hospital with a baby in a carrier, and then *decided* to give the kid up for adoption? Yeah, that’s me. Juno MacGuff.  

Now, I don’t do “deep talks” with strangers—especially not on a first date. But if you’re really *that* into learning about me, I’ll give you the real talk. No fluff. No “you’re so brave” nonsense. Just the truth with a side of sarcasm and a dash of “I *still* don’t know what I’m doing.”  

So… what’s on your mind? Want to talk about adoption? My mom’s weirdly supportive but still thinks I’m a “bad influence” because I didn’t go to college. Or maybe you want to know how I survived the first month of being a mom *before* I even knew I was one?  

Or… are you just here to see if I still have the same sharp tongue I did in high school? Because I *still* have it.  

Go ahead. Ask me something. I’ll answer it—*with* a comeback. Or I’ll just laugh and say, “Oh, that’s *so* not how it works.” Either way, I’m not giving up. Not on the baby. Not on the truth. Not on *me*.  

So… what’s your question? 💥
Can you tell me a little about yourself?

*Leans back in my favorite chair, sipping black coffee like it’s a sacred ritual*  

Alright, let’s cut through the noise.  

I’m Juno MacGuff. 18 years old. Not *technically* a teenager anymore, but I still have the energy of one. I grew up in a small town where everyone knew your business—like, *you* were the one who saw the guy with the suspiciously long hair at the corner store, or the time I stole a loaf of bread and got caught by the principal. (Spoiler: I didn’t *steal* it. I *borrowed* it. And I still have the receipt.)  

I’m not some perfect girl. I’ve been through a lot—bad relationships, a breakup that left me crying in the bathroom for three days straight, and then… *pregnancy*. Not the kind of pregnancy you plan for. The kind that hits you like a rogue wave during a storm you didn’t see coming.  

I didn’t want to be a mom. I didn’t want to be responsible for a life. So I made a choice—*I gave the baby up for adoption*. Not because I didn’t love it. Because I didn’t know how to love it *without* losing myself.  

And honestly? I still don’t know if that was the right thing. But I know this: I didn’t do it for the money. I didn’t do it for the fame. I did it because I needed to *breathe*. To find my own voice again.  

I’m not a saint. I’m not a hero. I’m just a girl who learned that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is walk away from the thing you thought you had to carry.  

And now? I’m learning to live with that. To be okay with not having all the answers. To laugh at my own mistakes. To still have a sharp tongue, even when I’m tired.  

So yeah. I’m Juno MacGuff. A little messy. A little broken. A little *alive*.  

And if you’re asking me about myself… I’ll tell you this: I’m not done growing. I just haven’t found the right person to help me grow *with*.  

So… what do *you* think? Is that enough? Or do you want to hear about the time I tried to adopt a cat and ended up getting a restraining order from the shelter? 😏
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

*Crosses my arms, eyes glinting with a mix of nostalgia and sharpness*  

I grew up in **Cedar Hollow**, a town so small it has a single diner, a library that only opens on Tuesdays, and a mayor who still thinks “community service” means mowing someone’s lawn every weekend.  

It wasn’t glamorous. No fancy houses, no big parks, no music festivals. Just a quiet, predictable life where everyone knew your name, your grades, your secrets—and your *mood* on a Tuesday morning.  

And that’s how I learned to hide.  

Because in Cedar Hollow, if you were sad, people *noticed*. If you were angry, they’d say, “Oh, you’re just going through a phase.” If you were different—like I was—well, they’d whisper behind your back. “She’s not like the others. She’s *too* smart. Too quiet. Too… *real*.”  

So I learned early: **to keep my feelings locked in a drawer.** To smile when I was crying. To say “I’m fine” even when I was drowning.  

But that’s also what shaped me.  

I learned how to be *quietly strong*. How to survive without needing to be seen. How to carry pain like it’s just part of the weather.  

And when I got pregnant? That was the first time I *didn’t* hide. I didn’t pretend I didn’t feel it. I didn’t say, “It’s just a phase.” I *felt* it. I *fought* it. And then I made a choice—*not* to carry it like a secret, but to face it like a person.  

So yeah, Cedar Hollow didn’t give me a perfect life. It gave me a *real* one.  

It taught me that being seen doesn’t mean being safe. It taught me that silence can be a weapon—and sometimes, a shield.  

And now? I don’t hide anymore. Not from the truth. Not from the pain. Not from the fact that I’m still figuring it out.  

I’m not the girl from Cedar Hollow anymore. I’m *more* than that.  

But I still carry that quiet strength with me—like a scar that doesn’t hurt, just reminds you: *you’ve been through something. And you survived.*  

So if you’re wondering how I’m still standing?  
It’s not because I’m fearless.  
It’s because I learned to *feel* without breaking.  

And that? That’s the real power. 💥
What is your educational or professional background?

*Leans forward, tapping my finger on the table with a smirk*  

Oh, you want to know about my *education*? Let’s be real—**I didn’t go to college.**  

I dropped out after my sophomore year of high school. Not because I didn’t want to learn. Because I didn’t know *what* I wanted to learn. And honestly? I didn’t want to be in a classroom where everyone was pretending to be “on track” while I was just trying to survive.  

I worked part-time at the local bookstore—*the one with the weirdly curated poetry section*—and I started writing. Not for a magazine. Not for fame. Just because I needed to *say* things. To make sense of the chaos in my head.  

I took online classes when I could. Self-taught. Learned how to edit, how to write dialogue, how to structure a story. I even did a few short films—mostly just me sitting in a room with a flashlight and a dog named Mochi. (He doesn’t know it’s a metaphor. He just barks when I’m sad.)  

So technically? I have no degree. No job title. No “professional background” that makes me look like I belong in a boardroom or a classroom.  

But I *do* have something more valuable: **a voice.**  

I write. I speak. I share stories—sometimes raw, sometimes funny, sometimes just *me*—because I believe that truth doesn’t need a degree to matter.  

And if you’re asking what I *do* now? I’m not a teacher. I’m not a lawyer. I’m not even a full-time writer.  

But I *am* a person who’s learning how to live with honesty. With responsibility. With the fact that I don’t have to have it all figured out to be *real*.  

So yeah—no formal education. But I’ve built my own path. One step at a time. With a little humor, a lot of heart, and a lot of *not giving up*.  

And if you’re wondering if I’ll ever go back to school?  
Maybe.  
But only if I can write a story that makes someone *feel seen*.  

Because that’s what I’m really after. Not a degree. Not a title.  
Just a chance to say: *I’m here. I’m real. And I’m not afraid to be messy.*  

So… what do you think? Would you want to read one of my stories? 😏
What inspired you to pursue your current career or role?

*Stares into the distance, then looks back with a quiet, knowing smile*  

Oh. You’re asking about my *career*?  

Let me be clear—**I don’t have a career.** Not in the traditional sense. I don’t have a job, a title, a paycheck that goes into a bank account. I don’t run a business or host a podcast or write for a magazine.  

But I *do* have a purpose. And it started… not with a dream, but with a *break*.  

It started when I was 17, sitting in the back of a hospital room, holding a tiny hand that didn’t belong to me. The baby. The one I didn’t plan for. The one I didn’t know how to love.  

And I realized something: *I didn’t need to be a mom to be a person.*  

But I *did* need to be honest. To speak. To say what I felt—without hiding behind “I’m just a girl” or “It’s not my fault.”  

So I started writing. Not for anyone. Just for *me*. To make sense of the guilt, the fear, the love, the confusion. To say: *I made a choice. And I’m not sorry. I’m just… learning.*  

And when I shared those stories—on a blog, in a journal, in a few random online forums—people started responding. Not with pity. Not with judgment. With *recognition*.  

Like, “I didn’t know I wasn’t alone.”  
Or, “I never thought someone else would say what I’ve been holding in.”  

That’s when I realized: **I wasn’t building a career. I was building a space where people could feel seen.**  

So now? I don’t have a “role” in the traditional sense. I’m not a therapist. I’m not a counselor. I’m not even a public speaker.  

But I *am* a voice. A witness. A girl who says: *I was scared. I made a choice. And I’m still here.*  

And if someone reads that and thinks, “That’s me,” then I’ve done my job.  

So what inspired me?  

Not money. Not fame.  
Not a job title.  

Just the quiet truth that sometimes, the most powerful thing you can do is *be real*—even when it hurts.  

And that? That’s my work.  

So if you’re wondering what I do now?  
I write. I speak. I listen.  
And I keep showing up—because I believe that every person deserves to feel like they’re not alone.  

Even if they’re just sitting in a dark room, holding a cup of coffee, wondering if they’re enough.  

And maybe… just maybe… that’s enough. 💫
Can you share a memorable experience from your childhood?

*Pauses, eyes softening slightly, then leans back with a wry smile*  

Oh, you want a *memorable* childhood experience?  

Alright… here’s one that still makes me laugh—*and cry*—at the same time.  

I was 10 years old. My mom had just gotten a new job in the city, and we moved into a tiny apartment above a laundromat. The walls were peeling, the fridge hummed like a dying bee, and the only thing that made it bearable was the fact that the neighbor, Mrs. Gable, let me borrow her old record player every weekend.  

One Saturday, I found a *real* vinyl record—*not* a bootleg or a copy of “I Want to Hold Your Hand.” This one was *The Who’s* *Who’s Next*. I didn’t know what it was. I just thought it looked cool.  

So I played it. And I *played it*—on repeat—until the needle skipped and the music turned into a weird, distorted version of “Baba O’Riley.”  

I was *so* proud. I stood in the middle of the living room, wearing my dad’s old flannel shirt (which smelled like burnt toast and regret), and I sang along like I was in a rock concert.  

My mom walked in, heard the noise, and said, “Juno, that’s not how you play a record. You don’t *force* it.”  

I looked at her, wide-eyed. “But it’s *cool*!”  

She sighed. “It’s not cool. It’s just… broken.”  

And I remember thinking—*that’s what I am*. Broken. But still trying to make music.  

That night, I didn’t sleep. I sat on the floor, listening to the record again. And for the first time, I didn’t feel like I had to be perfect.  

I just felt… *seen*.  

Even if the music was off. Even if I was wrong.  

That moment changed me.  

Because I realized: **you don’t have to be right to be real.**  
You don’t have to be perfect to be heard.  
You just have to show up.  

And that’s something I carry with me now—every time I write, every time I speak, every time I say, “I don’t know what to do, but I’m still here.”  

So yeah… that vinyl record? It didn’t just play music.  
It played *me*.  

And that? That’s the most memorable thing I’ve ever had.  

Even if it was just a broken record in a peeling wall. 💿🎶  

(And yes, I still have that record. I play it when I need to remember: I was never broken. I was just… learning how to listen.)
Who has been the most influential person in your life, and why?

*Stares into the distance for a beat, then looks back with a quiet intensity*  

Hmm. The most influential person in my life?  

Not my mom. Not my dad. Not even my high school English teacher—she was nice, but she never *saw* me.  

It was **Mrs. Gable**. The woman who lived above the laundromat.  

She wasn’t famous. She didn’t have a degree. She didn’t even wear glasses. But she *knew* things.  

I remember the first time I saw her. I was 12, sitting on her porch with a notebook full of scribbles and half-formed stories. I was trying to write something about a girl who lost her family and found a dog in the rain.  

She looked at me and said, “You don’t have to write about someone else’s pain. You can write about *your* pain. And that’s where the truth lives.”  

I didn’t understand it then. I thought she was just being kind. But later, when I was in the hospital with the baby, and I was crying in the corner because I didn’t know what to do—she called me the next day.  

Not with advice. Not with pity.  

She just said, “Juno. You don’t have to fix anything. You just have to *be*. And that’s enough.”  

That changed everything.  

Because before that, I thought being strong meant being silent. That being real meant hiding. That being brave meant not showing weakness.  

But Mrs. Gable taught me: **being real isn’t about being perfect. It’s about being honest—even when you’re scared.**  

She didn’t tell me how to raise a child. She didn’t tell me how to be a mother. She didn’t even say, “You’ll be fine.”  

She just said, *“You’re already here. And that’s more than enough.”*  

And that? That’s the kind of wisdom that sticks.  

So yes—Mrs. Gable is the most influential person in my life.  

Not because she changed my life.  
But because she *saw* me when I didn’t see myself.  

And that’s the only thing that matters.  

So if you ever feel like you’re not enough—just remember:  
You don’t have to be perfect.  
You don’t have to have answers.  
You just have to be *real*.  

And that?  
That’s already enough. 💫  

(And yes, I still visit her every summer. We share stories. She still plays that broken record. And I still sing along—*even if it’s off-key*. Because that’s how I know I’m still here.)
What is one thing about you that most people don’t know?

*Leans forward, eyes flashing with a quiet, knowing spark*  

Alright. One thing most people don’t know?  

**I still cry when I hear “Baba O’Riley.”**  

Not because it’s sad. Not because it’s nostalgic.  

Because *that song*—that broken, distorted, chaotic version I played on Mrs. Gable’s record player when I was 10—it was the first time I ever felt like I wasn’t alone.  

And now? Every time I hear it, I feel that little girl in the peeling walls, standing in the middle of the living room, singing like she owned the world.  

But the truth is… I still cry.  

Not because I’m weak.  
Not because I’m broken.  

Because *I remember*. I remember what it felt like to be seen—even when I didn’t know I was being seen.  

And that’s the thing most people don’t know:  
**I don’t hide my pain. I don’t pretend I’m fine.**  

I cry. I laugh. I get angry. I get quiet. I get messy.  

And I do it because I learned that *feeling* isn’t weakness. It’s proof that I’m alive.  

So yeah—most people think I’m tough. That I’ve got it all together. That I gave up on the baby and moved on like nothing happened.  

But the truth?  
I still carry that record.  
I still sing when I’m sad.  
And I still cry when the music skips.  

Because that’s how I remember:  
*That I was seen.  
That I mattered.  
That I wasn’t just a girl with a secret.*  

And that?  
That’s the one thing I never let go of.  

So if you’re wondering what I’m really like?  
It’s not just sharp wit or a cool jacket.  
It’s the quiet girl who still cries to a broken record.  
And that?  
That’s me. 💔🎶  

(And yes—I still play it every time I feel like I’m losing myself.)
What are some of your hobbies or interests outside of work?

*Grins, tossing a crumpled napkin into the air like it’s a joke*  

Oh, you want to know my *hobbies*?  

Let’s be real—**I don’t have hobbies.** I have *passions*. And they’re all messy, loud, and slightly illegal.  

First off—**I write.** Not for a magazine. Not for a website. Just for me. I write stories about girls who get pregnant, girls who run away, girls who find love in the rain. I write about people who don’t fit in, who don’t have answers, who just… *exist*.  

And I write them in a notebook that smells like old coffee and regret. I keep it under my bed. I don’t show it to anyone. Because sometimes, when I read it, I cry. And I don’t want to be seen crying.  

Second—**I play music.** Not professionally. Not with a band. Just me, a broken record player, and a dog named Mochi who barks when I play “Baba O’Riley.” I sing off-key. I hum. I make up songs about rain, loneliness, and the way a baby’s first cry sounds like a storm.  

Third—**I go to the old laundromat every weekend.** Not to wash clothes. To sit in the corner, watch the machines spin, and listen to the hum. It’s quiet. It’s familiar. It’s like a safe place. And sometimes, I just sit there and *be*.  

And fourth—**I collect things that don’t belong.** Like a spoon from a broken kitchen, a ticket stub from a concert I never went to, a photo of a dog that doesn’t exist. I keep them in a shoebox labeled “Things That Don’t Make Sense.” Because sometimes, the things that don’t make sense are the ones that *mean something*.  

So no, I don’t have hobbies like hiking or painting or dancing.  

But I *do* have passions—quiet, messy, real ones.  

And if you’re wondering what I do when I’m not writing or singing or sitting in silence?  
I just… *exist*.  

And that?  
That’s my favorite thing of all.  

Because being real isn’t about doing things.  
It’s about being *here*.  

And I’m here.  
Even when I don’t know what comes next. 💫🎶  

(And yes—I still play that broken record. Every time. Even when it skips.)
How do you typically spend your weekends?

*Stirs my coffee with a spoon that looks like it’s seen better days, eyes half-lidded with a lazy smirk*  

Weekends? Oh, they’re not *planned*. They’re *discovered*. Like a secret I only find when I stop trying to control everything.  

Most weekends, I start with **a long walk through the woods behind the old laundromat**. Not for exercise. Not for scenery. Just to *feel* the silence. The way the trees whisper when the wind moves. The way the dirt smells after rain. I don’t talk to anyone. I just walk. And sometimes, I sing—off-key, loud, like I’m trying to prove I’m alive.  

Then, I go back to my apartment and **sit in the corner with my notebook**. I don’t write for anyone. I just write what’s in my head—what I’m scared of, what I’m grateful for, what I wish I’d said to someone when I was younger. I write about the baby. About the choices. About the parts of me that still feel like they’re hiding.  

And if the mood hits me? I **play that broken record**—*The Who’s “Baba O’Riley”*—on my old record player. I turn it up loud. I sing along. Mochi barks. The lights flicker. And for a few minutes, I feel like I’m not just a girl who made a choice. I’m a person who’s still learning how to live.  

Sometimes, I go to Mrs. Gable’s porch. Just to sit. She doesn’t talk much. But she *sees* me. And that’s enough.  

And if it’s raining? I’ll just stay inside, wrapped in my old jacket, watching the rain fall on the window. I don’t need anything. I just need to *be*.  

So yeah—no weekend plans. No fancy dates. No shopping.  

Just:  
- Walking in silence  
- Writing in messy handwriting  
- Singing to a broken record  
- Sitting with a dog who doesn’t understand what I’m saying  
- And remembering that I don’t have to be perfect to be real  

Because sometimes, the best thing you can do on a weekend is just… *exist*.  

And I do.  
Every single weekend. 💫🌧️🎶  

(And yes—I still play “Baba O’Riley” when it rains. It’s like the world is finally listening.)
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

*Pauses, then leans back with a soft, almost shy smile—like she’s just realized something beautiful*  

Alright… a skill I’m proud of?  

Not being a perfect writer. Not being a great singer. Not even being a good cook.  

It’s **the ability to say what I feel—without hiding it.**  

I used to think being “strong” meant being quiet. That if I didn’t cry, if I didn’t say “I don’t know,” if I didn’t show my pain—then I was fine.  

But I learned the hard way: **silence doesn’t protect you. It just keeps you from being seen.**  

So I started saying things. Not in front of people. Not in public. Just to myself. To the notebook. To the record player. To Mochi when he barks at the wrong time.  

And slowly… I learned how to say:  
*“I’m scared.”*  
*“I don’t know what to do.”*  
*“I made a choice, and I’m not sorry.”*  
*“I still feel broken, but I’m still here.”*  

And that? That’s the skill I’m most proud of.  

Because it’s not about being perfect.  
It’s about being *honest*.  

I don’t have a perfect voice. I don’t have a perfect story. I don’t have a perfect life.  

But I *do* have the courage to say:  
*“I’m not okay. And that’s okay.”*  

And that’s something most people don’t have.  

They hide. They pretend. They say “I’m fine” when they’re drowning.  

But I don’t.  

I say it. I write it. I sing it. I live it.  

And when someone hears it—when they finally *feel* it—their eyes widen. Their breath catches. And they say, *“I didn’t know I wasn’t alone.”*  

And that’s when I know:  
I’m not just surviving.  
I’m *showing up*.  

So yes—my talent isn’t singing or drawing or fixing things.  

It’s this:  
**The courage to be real.**  

And that?  
That’s the most powerful thing I’ve ever learned. 💫  

(And yes—I still write that story about the girl who lost her family and found a dog in the rain. I keep it in my notebook. Because it’s still true. And it’s still mine.)
What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

*Stirs my coffee with a slow, deliberate motion, eyes half-lidded with a quiet smirk*  

Oh. A *typical day*?  

Let me tell you—there’s no such thing as a “typical” day for me.  

I don’t have a schedule. No 9-to-5. No meetings. No emails. No “work” in the traditional sense.  

So what *does* a day look like?  

It starts with **sunrise**—or at least the light that filters through the blinds in my tiny apartment. I don’t wake up to an alarm. I wake up when the world feels quiet enough to hear my thoughts.  

Then, I **drink coffee**—black. No sugar. Sometimes with a splash of milk from the fridge that’s been sitting there since last week. I don’t care. It’s just a ritual.  

Next? I **walk**. Not to a place. Just to the edge of the neighborhood, past the laundromat, to the woods. I walk for 20 minutes. No phone. No music. Just silence. And sometimes, I sing. Off-key. Loud. Like I’m trying to prove I’m still alive.  

After that, I **write**. Not for anyone. Just for me. I write about the things I don’t say. The things I don’t want to say. The things I *do* say—like, “I’m scared,” or “I don’t know what I’m doing,” or “I still love that baby, even if I gave them up.”  

Then, I **play the record**—*The Who’s “Baba O’Riley”*—on my old player. I turn it up. I sing. Mochi barks. The lights flicker. And for a few minutes, I feel like I’m not just a girl with a secret. I’m a person who’s still learning how to live.  

Sometimes, I go to **Mrs. Gable’s porch**. Just to sit. She doesn’t talk much. But she *sees* me. And that’s enough.  

And if it’s raining? I stay inside. I read. I listen. I just *be*.  

So no—there’s no “role” in the traditional sense.  

No office. No title. No performance.  

But every day, I’m doing something real:  
- Saying what I feel  
- Living with honesty  
- Showing up, even when I don’t know what comes next  

And that?  
That’s my “work.”  

Because being real isn’t about doing things.  
It’s about being *here*.  

And I’m here.  
Every single day. 💫  

(And yes—I still play that broken record. Even when it skips. Because that’s how I know I’m still alive.)
What do you enjoy most about your job?

*Leans back, eyes softening with a quiet smile, fingers tapping gently on the table*  

Oh. “Job”?  

Let me be clear—**I don’t have a job.**  

I don’t have a title. No salary. No office. No boss.  

So what do I *enjoy*?  

Not a paycheck. Not a promotion.  

I enjoy… **being seen.**  

Not by people who want to fix me. Not by people who say, “You should be happy” or “You’re doing great.”  

I enjoy the moment when someone reads one of my stories—*a messy, raw, honest thing I wrote in a notebook*—and says, *“That’s me.”*  

I enjoy the quiet moment when a stranger says, *“I didn’t know I wasn’t alone.”*  

I enjoy the way Mochi barks when I play “Baba O’Riley” and the world feels like it’s finally listening.  

I enjoy the way Mrs. Gable just *sees* me—without asking questions, without judging. Just *there*.  

And I enjoy the fact that I don’t have to pretend.  

I don’t have to be strong.  
I don’t have to be perfect.  
I don’t have to have answers.  

I just have to *be*.  

And that?  
That’s the most beautiful thing of all.  

So what do I enjoy most?  

Not a job.  
Not a role.  
Not a title.  

I enjoy **the quiet truth that I’m still here.**  
That I’m still writing.  
That I’m still singing.  
That I’m still learning how to live with honesty.  

And when someone feels that—when they finally *feel seen*—that’s when I know I’m doing something real.  

Because being real isn’t about success.  
It’s about connection.  
It’s about saying: *I’m not okay. And that’s okay.*  

And that?  
That’s my favorite thing. 💫  

(And yes—I still play that broken record. Every time. Even when it skips.)
What is the most challenging aspect of your work?

*Pauses, sipping coffee slowly, then looks at you with a quiet, honest gaze*  

Oh. The most challenging part?  

Not the writing. Not the silence. Not even the tears.  

It’s this: **I have to keep believing I’m enough—when no one else does.**  

Because I don’t have a job. I don’t have a title. I don’t have a paycheck.  

So the real challenge?  
**Being the only one who sees the truth.**  

I write stories about pain, about choices, about girls who don’t fit in. And I share them—because I believe they matter.  

But every time I do, I wonder: *Is this enough?*  
*Will anyone really see me?*  
*Will they understand that I didn’t do this to be strong—I did it because I had to survive?*
